awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Multi-Objective Optimization via Simulation: Theory, Methods, and Parallel Computation
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant is developing theory, methods, and algorithms for decision-making under uncertainty in complex systems that are modeled using computer-based simulations. The speciﬁc focus will be on developing implementable algorithms that identify optimal decisions with respect to multiple performance measures. Such problems arise frequently in a variety of applications including ﬁnance, energy, transportation, facility location, supply chain management, telecommunication, and healthcare management. Though widespread, these problems are under-studied, and current solution methods may be slow, imprecise, or inaccurate. Developing methods to solve such problems with provable guarantees on speed, precision, and accuracy will enable decision-makers to make better, timely decisions across a variety of disciplines. Society will beneﬁt from improved systems, characterized by increased efﬁciency and reduced cost. This project also supports the PI's educational goal of disseminating clear and engaging educational materials at the interface of probability and optimization that recruit, train, and retain the next generation of professionals who make decisions under uncertainty.

This research will develop theory, methods, and parallel algorithms for solving multi-objective optimization via simulation problems. Multi-objective optimization via simulation problems are nonlinear multi-objective optimization problems in which each objective can only be observed with error as output from a Monte Carlo simulation; a solution to this problem is a non-dominated (Pareto) set. Despite its prevalence and mature development in the analogous deterministic context, multi-objective optimization via simulation problems have seen relatively little theoretical and algorithmic development in the optimization via simulation literature. These problems are difﬁcult to solve because of their complexity: the objective functions can only be estimated with error through potentially expensive Monte Carlo simulation, and the Pareto set often grows in the number of objectives. The proposed research will develop the theoretical underpinnings of estimating Pareto sets in the stochastic context. Speciﬁcally, the proposed theory and methods include scaling for dimension reduction, asymptotic approximation, optimization frameworks that retrieve fast convergence rates, and parallel implementation. Such understanding will lead to new algorithmic methods that evolve optimally in a provable sense and to implementable, efﬁcient parallel algorithms for solving these difficult problems.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the project include the development of theory, methods, and algorithms for multi-objective simulation optimization (MOSO) problems; that is, optimization problems in which a complex stochastic system is represented by a Monte Carlo simulation model, and the system is evaluated using multiple performance measures which are posed as simultaneous objectives. Such problems arise frequently in a variety of engineering applications including agriculture, ﬁnance, energy, transportation, facility location, supply chain management, telecommunication, and healthcare management. For example, our work has been used to assist plant breeders in solving the mating design problem when progeny can be simulated and to solve a bi-objective hospital resource allocation problem.

 

Despite being widespread, MOSO problems are generally under-studied. Thus, when presented with such a problem, one might reformulate it into a single-objective problem, e.g., by selecting one performance measure as the objective and posing the rest as constraints. However, solving the reformulated problem yields only one estimated solution. If we instead pose and solve the problem in its multi-objective form, we yield an entire set of estimated efficient points in the decision space and their estimated images in the objective space, called the estimated Pareto set. While computationally intensive, the ability to solve such problems in this fashion provides a decision-maker with far more information on the tradeoffs between the objectives. This broader view of the problem can lead to better decision-making.

 

Toward solving these difficult but important problems, the project yielded theory, methods, and algorithms for MOSO problems classified into three categories based on the nature of the decision variables. The first category contains MOSO problems in which the decision variables can only take on values in a finite set, called multi-objective ranking and selection (MORS) problems. The second category contains MOSO problems in which the decision variables can take on integer values that have physical meaning to the decision maker (such as the amount of stock to order or the number of hospital beds to allocate), called MOSO problems on integer lattices. The third category contains MOSO problems in which the decision variables can only take on values in some interval subset of the real numbers, called continuous MOSO problems.

 

Toward solving MORS problems, the project yielded fundamental theoretical advances in the understanding of asymptotically optimal sampling allocations. It also yielded implementable and parallelizable algorithms based on these theoretical advances. Software for these algorithms is currently publicly available in a repository.

 

Toward solving MOSO problems on integer lattices, the project yielded a new family of provably efficient and convergent retrospective approximation algorithms. Within this family, the project yielded the competitive benchmark R-MinRLE algorithm and the state-of-the-art R-PERLE algorithm for solving bi-objective MOSO problems on integer lattices. Both algorithms are designed to obtain simulation replications in parallel. Software containing parallel implementations of these algorithms is publicly available through the PyMOSO software package.

 

Toward solving continuous MOSO problems, the project yielded new upper bounds on the Hausdorff distance between a Pareto set and its discretization in bi-objective convex quadratic optimization. This advance is a first step in obtaining performance bounds on algorithms for continuous MOSO problems, which also can be used in algorithm design.

 

The project has contributed to the mentoring and training of one postdoc and numerous graduate and undergraduate students. It also resulted in two literature reviews and tutorials, one of which was written entirely with graduate student co-authors and contributed to their training. The project yielded significant improvements to the PI's large undergraduate probability course, which has trained nearly one thousand students to date. Further, journal papers and conference proceedings document the technical results, and publicly available software enables the adoption of the new state-of-the-art methods by engineers across a variety of disciplines.
